Facility: African American Cultural and Heritage Facility
Survey Item: Please let us know if you have any additional feedback about the AACHF's facilities.
Response: The dance studio floor is consistently dirty, often with debris on the floor which can be hazardous to dancers' feet (small pebbles; I've even found curtain rod hooks and metal wires ON THE FLOOR). The carpet runners provided from the time the facility opened appear to have not been cleaned since they were installed; I have to sweep the floor every time I use the facility. The bathroom is consistently out of soap; the toilet has a nasty "ring" in the bowl, as if it hasn't been scrubbed in years, and the floor does not appear to have EVER been mopped! The mirrors are smeared with fingerprints and have "pock marks"/damage. The "marley" covering the floor is puckering and the tape that binds it together is frayed, creating trip hazards. The space in general is WAAY too small; I don't know who decided such a small space was adequate to accommodate the myriad of cultural/artistic needs of the Black community; it appears the space was built without any real thought as to our needs. Instead of a tiny meeting room and tiny dance studio, MUCH larger facilities are needed; in addition to a larger meeting space and dance studio, there should've been a performance hall and SEVERAL meeting rooms (some small, and at least one large one). It appears the powers that be approved the construction of this tiny, inadequate space so it can say they did "something" for the Black community. I have been to the Mexican-American Cultural Center and the Asian-American Cultural Center; BOTH have facilities which are FAR-LARGER and more accommodating than the tiny "bone" "thrown" to Austin Blackfolk. Why was it determined our facility deserved to be the TINIEST and LEAST-APPOINTED?
